questions.question: Where can a local variable be accessed?

options.text: Only inside the function where it was created
In any function that calls that function
In the main body of the file

questions.explanation: Local variables are only visible within the scope of the function that defines them.

questions.question: What keyword is used to modify a global variable from inside a function?
questions.explanation: The 'global' keyword tells Python you want to use the global version of a variable rather than creating a local one.

questions.question: If a global variable and a local variable have the same name, which one does the function use by default?
questions.explanation: Python prioritizes local scope. If a name exists in local scope, it 'shadows' the global variable of the same name.

questions.question: Is it generally considered good practice to use many global variables?

options.text: Yes, it makes variables easy to find
No, it makes code harder to maintain and test

questions.explanation: Good code design prefers passing data via parameters and return values to keep functions isolated and predictable.
